fields.description:
Given I am in a local git repository
 And I am on branch "br1"
 And "br1" is currently at commit "c1"
 And my working directory contains a file named "some_file"
 And "some_file" is tracked by git
 And there exists a second branch "br2"
 And "br2" is at the same commit "c1" as "br1"
 When I commit "some_file" deletion on "br1"
 And I checkout branch "br2"
 Then "br1" is at commit "c2" > "c1"
 And "br2" is at commit "c1"
 And current branch is "br2"
 When I commit an updated version of "some_file" on "br2"
 Then "br2" is at commit "c3" != "c2"
 When I switch back to branch "br1"
 And I merge "br2" into "br1"
 Then a "deleted/modified file" conflict for "some_file" is reported by git

When I use Sourcetree's Resolve Conflicts > Resolve Using "Mine", I expect to confirm the deletion of "some_file".
 Instead, your working directory contains "some_file" with the content committed in "br2".
 This scenario is the same as if you had chosen Resolve Conflicts > Resolve Using "Theirs".

This behaviour is different than plain command-line Git's, which allows you to "git add/rm "some_file"" to either:
 - "add" "some_file" back from "br2" (similar to "resolve using theirs"), or
 - "rm" "some_file" confirming "br1"'s change (similar to expected "resolve using mine").
fields.summary: Wrong "deleted/modified file" conflict resolution using Resolve Conflicts > Resolve Using "Mine"

fields.description:
I am so frustrated that this issue has been going on for far too long. 

 

First, let me point out, this all started when everytime you go to push new changes, authentication failed because of too many failed attempts. I am already logged in, and have only logged in once successfully, so that is untrue. Remove that BS from preventing actual successful logins. *Fix your code*

 

Second, every day it seems as though I open source tree and now it says authentication failed because of incorrect password/email. Like seriously? So I remove my account and re-add it, and it works, with the SAME INFORMATION AS BEFORE. Tomorrow it will do the same thing. Oh and when you do that, you must re-pair your repositories. 

 

What the hell updates are you releasing because each one is causing more problems then the previous, I have been using Source Tree for years, (since it was publically available) just in the last 2 months this crap has been happening and I'm to the point annoyed of leaving and finding a better solution to my Git GUI. 

 

The biggest disappointment is trying to push new updates and seeing "AUTHENTICATION FAILED"... Do we need Bio Scanners, retina scanners for my eyes, I mean cmon, stop the stupid authentication problems. I am Logged in, I have NOT LOGGED OUT. 

 

I am sorry for my tone, but I'm pissed. I've asked you guys to fix this for months, I've requested this to be looked at and yet you guys cannot fix the problem.

SourceTree 2.7 added a "Build Status" column to the History Workspace.

While useful if you're using Bitbucket, it's unnecessary and obtrusive if you're using another Git host.

I asked on [Twitter|https://twitter.com/FluxSauce/status/951875555682500609] how to disable this advertisement, and Brian Ganninger replied with instructions on how to do it for a single repository (View -> Hide Build Status).

However, I've got dozens of repositories and manually setting that flag for every repository is an unnecessary chore.

Would it be possible to provide an application-wide preference to disable the Build Status, or possibly a bulk update option to save time?

Thanks!

fields.description:
The Push command very kindly warns you if a submodule has unpushed commits, and lets you push the submodule first. However, *it doesn't do this if the submodule is in "detached HEAD" state*, i.e. no branch is checked out. Unfortunately, submodules are very often in this state because the `git submodule update` command leaves them that way. The result is that SourceTree pushes the main repo without the dependent submodule commit, leaving the upstream/remote repo in a broken state, causing build failures and annoyed messages from co-workers.

I cannot count how many times I've broken a build by forgetting to push a submodule that has new commits, because I tend to rely on SourceTree to remind me.

This isn't a regression; it's been the case for years, I've just never gotten around to filing a bug report until now...

Steps to reproduce:
 # Open a repo that has a submodule, and open the submodule
 # Make and commit (to master) a change in the submodule
 # Commit the submodule change to the main repo's master branch.
 # Check out an older commit in the main repo (resets the submodule to an older commit)
 # Check out the master branch in the main repo (resets the submodule to the new commit, but does _not_ check out the submodule's master branch)
 # Push the main repo

Expected Result:
 * Unpushed-submodules sheet opens and prompts me to push the submodule

Actual Result:
 * Sheet does not open, and main repo is immediately pushed, without the dependent submodule commit (breaking the build on the remote of course)
fields.summary: No unpushed-submodule warning if submodule is in detached HEAD

fields.description:
I have a private gitlab server that is authenticated with LDAP(Active Directory). When SourceTree is open I sporadically get locked out of my Active Directory account. After researching the lockout. My support team has identified the source as the gitlab server. 

I handle the majority of my pulls, push, branches, merges, through the command line but I find SourceTree to be useful with merge conflicts, rebasing and general visualization of the repository. 

I have no accounts provisioned within SourceTree, I have turned off the following settings
 * Check default remotes for updates
 * Refresh automatically when files change
 * I have also disabled these settings in the Repository Settings as well.

Additional Info: 
 * I can go weeks without opening SourceTree and I am not locked out of my active directory account. 
 * Within hours, sometimes minutes of opening SourceTree I will be locked out of my Active Directory account. Every time support tracks it to gitlab soon after I have opened SourceTree.

Steps I've taken to resolve
 * I have searched console.app for all SourceTree logs and I cannot find any Authentication logs, or failures. 
 * I have removed all references of gitlab, Active Directory, and SourceTree from my keychain. 
 * I have repeatedly, removed files from ~/Library/Application Support/SourceTree that have to do with authentication <username>@STAuth-<serverFQDN> However the file keeps getting recreated. its contents look to be jumbled binary. 
 * I have Restarted SourceTree, this is typically when a lockout will occur
 * I have Uninstalled and Reinstalled SourceTree
 * I have Uninstalled and removed all traces of SourceTree 'rm -rf' of directories and files 

the Issue persists. I would be grateful for any tips, log locations or any information that could help solve this issue for me.
fields.summary: SourceTree

fields.description:
I have a bookmark for a Git repo containing a directory with a npm package.json file. `npm install` in this dir creates/updates ~200k files in `node_modules` subdir.

My `~/.gitignore_global` contains (amongst others)
{code:java}
node_modules/
bin/ {code}
The repo `.gitignore` also contains
{code:java}
node_modules/{code}
When I start SourceTree, the app works as expected. In the window for the above repo, Workspace > File status for "All files" doesn't show files that should be ignored.

If I delete the `node_modules` directory, SourceTree hangs, displaying the spinning "beachball" for ~2-3 minutes. Behaviour is similar when using `npm install` to populate the dir, or to make large updates to the dir.

This occurs even if the repo window isn't open but the repository browser window is open.

`git status` executes swiftly.

Expected behaviour: since `node_modules` is ignored, changes to files in this directory shouldn't cause noticeable effects to SourceTree.

Attaching:
 * [^sourcetree-sample.txt] - Sample of app in "hanging" state, taken using Activity Monitor
 * [^sourcetree-spindump.txt] - Spindump of app in "hanging" state taken using Activity Monitor
fields.summary: App hangs for 2-3 minutes during/after changes to many files in ignored dir (eg node_modules)

fields.description:
Hi, Atlassian.

I'm using SourceTree with some repos that have a very long commit history. For example, [https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core,] which has 830,000 commits as of this writing.

Today, I wanted to roll my homebrew-core repo back to mid-February. To do this, I opened up the repo (at /usr/local/Homebrew/Library/Taps/homebrew/homebrew-core on my Mac) in SourceTree, and started scrolling down the commit history by dragging the scrollbar's thumbnail (or whatever you call it) to the bottom. Each time I dragged it to the bottom, it would load some more history, and the thumbnail would jump back up a bit.

However, this took a _lot_ of repetitions of that scroll-to-the-bottom behavior to get all the way back to May. And each time I scrolled to the bottom, the thumbnail seemed to jump up less far in the scroll bar. I suspect this is because it was loading a fixed number of commit records (like 100 or 1,000?) each time I scrolled to the bottom.

Maybe the scroll bar behavior could be adjusted so that the number of new history records it loaded upon being scrolled to the bottom could be scaled to the number of history records that are already loaded: like, if there are 10,000 records displayed, load up 1,000 more, but if I've already loaded 100,000 records, load up 10,000 more at a time (i.e. 0.1*n), at the expense of a longer delay in UI responsiveness. That would make it easier to dredge through long repo histories.

Thanks for your consideration!

Cheers,
Andrew
fields.summary: Adaptive history scroll bar increments

fields.description:
[EDIT]

Sorry folks, the web-interface didn't make it clear the first "Submit" actually took. 

This is a 2nd submission that should be closed. The original (SRCTREE-5258) has attachments and should be the tracker of this issue.

I suggest closing this issue immediately to avoid confusion and duplicate work.

Pete (the originator)

 

Original below

–––––––––––––––––––––

 

Steps
 # cd to repo/subdir/ (or repo/subdir/sub-subdir) of a git repository
 # run alias 'x' or 'open . -a SourceTree'

Result
 * SourceTree presents a new dialog to "Create new repository" (see attachment)

Desired Behavior
 * The "Create new repository" should NOT show if I'm in a sub directory of an existing (git) repository
 * There should be an opt out checkbox in the preferences

Workaround
 * I can press the cancel button
 * I can only open the repo within Terminal from within the root directory of the repository (where the .git directory is).

Proposed Fixes
 * Traverse parent directories until you hit / (or some reasonable "top" level directory) looking for a '.git' directory
 * Run a git command in the loaded directory to test whether this path is already within a git repository
 * Let the user opt out of the "Create new repository" dialog.
fields.summary: DUPLICATE OF SRCTREE-5258 Offers to create repository inside another repository

fields.description:
Sourcetree slowed down significantly with the recent visual changes in 2.5 and 2.6 only barely improves this.  The diff viewer can take upwards of 30s for to view the changes in a small file.  Staging a chunk can take 15s.  I've reinstalled freshly but to no avail.  The code base has around 70k lines of C++ in a few hundred files.  Sourcetree < 2.5 coped just fine with this.  Now, it's practically unusable.  Worse still, the performance gets worse the longer the application is open.

I see a lot of the mac spinning wheel while I wait for simple interface actions like the context menu to appear.  I see the animated circle of lines on the file tree too.

I see these problems even on small git repositories, but it gets worse with larger repositories.

The basic functionally is severely impaired by the poor performance. This application unfortunately now is the least responsive application I use.  

I really like the ability to view and stage code chunks, but I'm unlikely to continue using sourcetree if I have to wait 20 - 50s to stage chunks of code.
fields.summary: Mac Performance Too Slow to be Useable

fields.description:
The embedded version of [Git LFS|https://git-lfs.github.com] used in Sourcetree for macOS was vulnerable to CVE-2017-17831. An attacker can exploit this issue if they can commit to a git repository linked in Sourcetree for macOS by adding a .lfsconfig file containing a malicious lfs url, allowing them to execute arbitrary code on systems running a vulnerable version of Sourcetree for macOS.  This vulnerability can also be triggered from a web page through the use of the Sourcetree URI handler.


*Affected versions:*
* Versions of Sourcetree for macOS starting with 2.1 before version 2.7.0 are affected by this vulnerability


*Fix:*
* Upgrade Sourcetree for macOS to version 2.7.0 or higher from https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/ .

For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/lIIyO].
fields.summary: Git LFS: Arbitrary command execution in repositories with Git LFS enabled - CVE-2017-17831

fields.description:
The embedded version of Mercurial used in Sourcetree for macOS was vulnerable to CVE-2017-17458. An attacker can exploit this issue if they can commit to a Mercurial repository linked in Sourcetree for macOS by adding a git subrepository specifying arbitrary code in the form of a .git/hooks/post-update script, allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary code on systems running a vulnerable version of Sourcetree for macOS. 
 Sourcetree for macOS performs background indexing which allows for this issue to be exploited without a user needing to directly interact with the git subrepository. From version 1.4.0 of Sourcetree for macOS, this vulnerability can be triggered from a webpage through the use of the Sourcetree URI handler.

*Affected versions:*
 * Versions of Sourcetree for macOS starting with 1.0b2 before version 2.7.0 are affected by this vulnerability

*Fix:*
 * Upgrade Sourcetree for macOS to version 2.7.0 or higher from [https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/] .

*Acknowledgements*
 Atlassian would like to credit Zhang Tianqi @ Tophant for reporting this issue to us.

For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/lIIyO].
fields.summary: Mercurial: arbitrary command execution in mercurial repositories with a git submodule  - CVE-2017-17458

fields.description:
Sourcetree for macOS had several argument and command injection bugs in Mercurial and Git repository handling. An attacker with permission to commit to a repository linked in Sourcetree for macOS is able to exploit this issue to gain code execution on the system. From version 1.4.0 of Sourcetree for macOS, this vulnerability can be triggered from a webpage through the use of the Sourcetree URI handler.

*Affected versions:*
 * Versions of Sourcetree for macOS starting with 1.0b2 before version 2.7.0 are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
 * Upgrade Sourcetree for macOS to version 2.7.0 or higher from [https://www.sourcetreeapp.com/] .

*Acknowledgements*
 Atlassian would like to credit Zhang Tianqi @ Tophant for reporting this issue to us.

For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/lIIyO].
fields.summary: Various argument and command injection issues in Sourcetree for macOS - CVE-2017-14592

fields.description:
It would be very useful to support the display (and creation) of marks against commits.
 A mark is a bit like a tag, except that many commits can have the same mark; a mark is metadata concerning a commit.

*Use case example, with imagined Sourcetree features:*

A user wants to be able to easily mark and see at a glance which commits are known to have compile issues. Similarly a mark for the commits which are refactor only (i.e. no functional change).

To set this up in Sourcetree, the user enters a marks setup dialog. They select "add item" and enter:
 * the text "compile fails"
 * they select a coloured shape from a choice (NB shape is for users with colour perception issues)

They hit ok, and select "add" again and enter:
 * the text "refactor only"
 * they select a (different to above) coloured shape from a choice

This entered info is optionally stored in a file in the actual repository itself, which would allow it to be shared with team members by pushing the file in usual way.

Now when viewing the git history in Sourcetree, there would be a convenient way for the user to apply or remove one of the marks from selected commit(s), e.g. a pressing a number key (preferred, as is quicker) or context menu. 
 When a commit has one or more of the marks applied to it, the configured coloured shapes are shown next to the commit message. Note that multiple markers can exist on same commit, hence multiple coloured shapes might be visible, and also that a many commits can have the same mark against it (which is a fundamental difference between a marker and a conventional tag).

Mouse-overing any mark for a commit pops up the definitions of the marks against the commit.

*Note:* showing of marks against commits should be presented visually in a way amenable to pre-attentive processing ([http://www.infovis-wiki.net/index.php/Preattentive_processing]), which is why I use coloured shapes in the example above. 
 It's important for user to easily grok the information at a glance. Showing say just the mark names against commits, without e.g. colouring, is not desirable, since this information is not pre-attentively processed by the brain.

*Note on possible implementation*

git notes seems to be an obvious way to implement this behind the scene. The single note permitted for a commit can store tags separated by some delimiter, e.g. "mark1|mark2"

Git supports notes being pushed to the remote repo, so sharing notes with all users of a repo should be possible.

The possible downside of using git notes for this is that any other use of git notes in a repo would clash with this feature's use of git notes. This issue could be avoided by using a different location to the default (refs/notes/commits) for the mark notes - see the --ref option of git notes.
fields.summary: Support configurable display of commit marks

(I was asked to open this ticket here: https://twitter.com/bgannin/status/938285211514822657)

https://www.transifex.com/atlassian/sourcetree-for-mac/language/en_GB/ currently has no strings Reviewed, because there are no Reviewers ([https://www.transifex.com/atlassian/teams/9869/en_GB/|https://www.transifex.com/atlassian/teams/9869/en_GB/).]).

I'd like to put myself forward as a Reviewer for en_GB. I am already a translator. I am based in the UK, and British English is my primary language.

I am a General Translation Editor and Locale Manager for British English for WordPress ([https://make.wordpress.org/polyglots/teams/?locale=en_GB)] - I translate, review and approve strings for WordPress Core, plugins, themes and related projects on an almost daily basis.

I use SourceTree for Mac every day, and while I recognise that there may only be a small percentage of strings in en_GB that differ from the default locale, it's important that these apparent "typos" and "unusual phrases" are addressed so British English speakers have a smoother user experience.

We often have multiple commits per day here so we're going to have to scroll up and down in that pane a lot more and lose at-a-glance recent history viewing.

I realise this is just a style issue and some users may like all the extra screen space with nothing in it - but can this at least be a preference/formatting option? (I've looked for one but can't find it).

fields.summary: SourceTree crashes with SEGFAULT sometimes after resuming from sleep on macOS High Sierra

fields.description:
When you have submodules added to your git repository, and you have changes in both the submodule and the git module itself (e.g your main code) Sourcetree asks you if you want to commit the changes in the submodule too. Which is great, it then shows a nice view in which you can decide what to commit and push from the submodule. 

However sometimes, I only have changes in the submodule. And from what I can tell there is no way to commit the changes in the submodule directly from SourceTree.
fields.summary: Committing submodule changes without module changes

fields.description:
*From the SourceTree repository window user can open terminal or windows explorer with 1 button (Buttons called "Terminal" and "Explorer" in the top right area).*

In many cases local project is a clone of a project in the cloud and that cloud version of the same project can be accessed via Web browser. 

In many cases of such cloud based projects the cloud repository is well known like BitBucket, GitHub, SourceTree, Boost, etc.

*It makes sense to provide one more "Cloud" button, which would just open Web Browser with he URL for the given project.*

For well known web locations you can provide a well formatted URL suitable for that particular cloud to target particular project. For unknown web location you can just open cloud website.

In all cases, it would be on user to provide all necessary cloud access credentials directly to the browser. Atlassian and SourceTree would not need them.

Exception: Atlassian, being the owner of SourceTree can provide even tighter integration with its own BitBucket cloud if it chooses for marketing purposes.
fields.summary: Provide button to open project website page

fields.description:
There are 2 issues in this bug:

In the SourceTree(Mac) version for Git mentioned below 2.6.3 (134)
 # Even after discarding a file or pushing to remote, the count of files is not updated on the SourceTree landing screen where all repositories are listed. This is very misleading and needs attention. The user has to manually do the "Refresh Remote Status" repeatedly to update the correct count.
 # After switching a branch, the new branch does not appear on the SourceTree landing screen. The only way to get it displayed is via killing the app i.e. Cmd+Q and then relaunch SourceTree

Please fix these as they are very misleading for the developer and cause a lot of confusion.

 

!image-2017-11-25-11-23-56-186.png!

!image-2017-11-25-11-24-41-583.png!

fields.description: The UI of the main window does not update which branch is active until a restart of the program. Switch branches all you want, it'll never change.
fields.summary: UI bug, active branch

fields.description:
I tried to update the SourceTree-Beta app and got an error alert:

"Sourcetree-Beta can’t be updated when it’s running from a read-only volume like a disk image or an optical drive. Move Sourcetree-Beta to Applications folder using Finder, relaunch it from there, and try again."

The app is not on a read-only volume nor in a disk image; it's in ~/Downloads which is of course writeable. I prefer not to move the app to /Applications since it's not a release version.
fields.summary: App falsely claims it can't be updated (it's not on a read-only volume)
File sorting by extension

fields.description:
After updating SourceTree I can no longer diff pbxproj. I have also set the file limits way beyond the size of my file, which has fixed this issue in the past.

Also, as you can see from the screenshot, the file selector shrink and I can not resize it. Only when selecting the pbxproj file, all other files allow it to be resized.
fields.summary: pbxproj diff appears as two images
